content.description:
Some slabby face moves lead to a powerful undercling, then a BIG reach or deadpoint to the base of a beautiful, but short, arching fingercrack layback flake.   

  This route got an X in the original guidebook, although the crux is pretty protectable.  The techy smears in the upper half make it a pretty heady lead, though.
content.protection: stoppers, tcu's, and a red camalot for the bottom.  For an anchor you can use a variety of cams from .75 camalot down to fingers sizes.
content.location: On the front side of Motorboat Rock, between two moderate cracks.

content.description: Access the seem and crack 5 ft right of Motor Boat by climbing the first 15' of Motor Boat then traversing right on thin holds. Mind the tree and don't fall. The name refers to the literal sandbag counter weight used to pull the rope and runner out of the crack and around the arete. The rating is thought to be accurate but who really knows.. Could be height dependent.
content.protection: Cams .4 to 4,  hook, mini trax, sandbag counter weight.
content.location: Look for pinch grip on right hand arete leading to the seem at its lowest point.

content.description: The slab and undercling at the start is the crux of the route. After that, everything is a cruise. A little crumbly at the top.
content.protection: Great Pro, medium sizes.  Boulders up top for anchors.
content.location: To the right of Shocker on the West side of Motorboat Rock.  The obvious right leaning crack.

content.description: This is a beautiful arching crack.  Good hand jams to start.  The dihedral very quickly forces you into powerful stemming.  Fist jams through the middle.  The crux is toward the top of the vertical crack when it widens and the dihedral constricts to force you out of it.  The flake behind your head is a great spot for your otherwise useless left hand.
content.protection: TR anchor from the boulder, walk off the same as other Motorboat Routes.  Medium to large pieces.
content.location: Northwest side of Motorboat Rock.  Past Can Opener and Shocker along the trail.

content.description: Start on the right side of the arête (same as Tarzan was a Bluesman)and clip 2 bolts then step left around the arête and continue working your way up using a combination of the arête and crack/seam on the left. 5 bolts, bolted anchor on top.
content.location: Technically on table rock, but located directly across from the climb Motorboat.

content.description: Start on Navy Route and about 15 feet off the ground, just when you get into the crack, move to the left and out onto the face.  Once on the face, you make some delicate moves upwards and towards knobs and crystals eventually making a powerful highstep up to the left to get onto the top edge.  Warning, a slip here could result in a large swing into the crack of Navy Route and injury potential.  Lieback this top edge upwards and to the right to finish at the anchors.
content.protection: Same anchors as for Navy Route, built anchor system.
content.location: Left of Navy Route and of course Shocker.  Motorboat Rock, Echo Canyon area.

content.description: Beautiful hand and fist crack in a tight corner. starts in a broken crack system and moves into 20 ft of continuous crack.
content.protection: Medium Pro #1-#4.  Boulder or gear anchor up top.
content.location: West face of Motorboat rock, just left of Shocker.

content.description: One fun face move brings you into a trough below a small roof.  Hand jam traverse under the roof with little feet before topping a ledge and finding the anchors.
content.protection: 2 top anchors.  BD #2 and #3 protect the crux.
content.location: SE corner of Motorboat rock.  Only route east of the Motorboat walk-off.

content.description: Bitch is the first climb encountered when approaching Motorboat along the purple climber�s trail.  Climb a short face to reach the crack above.  The crack starts about 1/3 of the way up the rock, and starts as an off-width that narrows as you climb higher.  Look for plenty of hidden holds inside the crack, some of which are a little rotten or crumbly.  The protection is good (large cams up to a #3.5 Camalot help), but the crack tends to throw you a little off balance.  At the top of the crack, face climb up good edges to the anchors.
content.protection: Standard rack with cams to a #3.5 Camalot.

content.description: SW side of Motorboat rock. To the right of detached boulder. Left of bastards moan. Starts on slab, climb into shallow cave with crack system to the left.
content.location: Front of Motorboat rock, just to the right of detached boulder.

content.description: Located just left of Beginner's Bitch.  Look for a wide crack up on the boulder with a slabby base.  The crux of the route is getting past the slab and into the crack.  Reach high for a decent hold, and then smear up the slab until you can step into the wide crack.  Once in the crack, the climbing is easy and straight forward with plenty of rests.  Almost felt like a chimney at times.  Ends at a two bolt anchor.

Motorboat Rock is the large boulder that sits at the entrance of the Echo Canyon climbing area.  There are a number of short climbs that range from 5.6 to 5.12 a/b X.  Most have top anchors that can be accessed easily from a gully on the corner closest to Throne Rock.  This area is very popular with guided groups and first time climbers.  Expect it to be mobbed with ropes hanging off nearly every climb on busy days.
